Discrete Morse theory and application in topological data analysis. Preface

Discrete Morse theory and application in topological data analysis. Emil Le 2021-03-27 Preface The full abstract can be access through this link. Medical data analysis has been growing as an important field that assist and process non-linear data. Applications can be of results from sub-field of computer vision, which includes difficult tasks such as segmentation and finding visual correspondence. However, there are many important practical invariant about medical data that are hard to incorporate in methodologies in a meaningful manners. Computational algebraic topology including persistence homology, one of the tool used in topological data analysis, rises as an approach to study the shape of high-dimensional data and provide dimensionality reduction method that is robust to noises. In this capstone project, we investigate on the algebraic version of Morse theory (discrete Morse theory) with its applications in medical image segmentation and gene co-expression network analysis. \[\text{Figure: Sublevel set persistence of a 3D plot.}\]

Chapter 1 Introduction 1.1 Motivation Topological data analysis (TDA) is field in applied mathematics that challenges the task of extracting and understand information of noisy and incomplete high-dimensional data, which in general is a difficult problem. As both global and local behavior of data are important, TDA aims to find the quantitative topological features that are robust. In differential topology, Morse theory analyzes differential functions (more specifically, the Morse functions) on manifolds to understand the topology of those manifolds. One of the basic results from Morse theory is that most functions on manifolds are Morse functions, and a good choice of a Morse function on a manifold can inform a lot about that manifold. Borrowing both ideas from TDA and Morse theory, discrete Morse theory is constructed in similar way in the combinatoric setting in order to compute the homology or denoise a space. 1.2 Morse Theory The fundamental idea of Morse theory is the invariant of critical points of a sensible differential function on a manifold, so what is consider a sensible function? In the simplest term, Morse functions are differential functions whose critical points satisfying some specific conditions. Before we get into this idea, let’s consider this example below to see that how the critical points are important information of a manifold. \[\text{Figure 1.1: Critical points of a terrain.}\] Example Let’s consider a unit sphere \(S^2\subset \mathbb{R}^3\) with a function that collapse the sphere into the \(z-\)axis: \[ \begin{aligned} S^2 = \{(x,y,z)&\vert x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1\} \\ \\ f\text{ }: S^2 &\longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \\ (x,y,z)&\longmapsto z \end{aligned} \] The gradient of \(f\) is \(\nabla f = [0 \text{ } 0 \text{ }1]^\text{T}\). Let \(m\in\mathbb{R}\), we can see that the critical point of \(f\) encodes information about the sub-level set of \(S^2\): Let \(m\subset \mathcal{R}\), consider the pre-image of M under \(f\): \[ f^{-1}(m) = \begin{cases} \emptyset &\text{ if } m < -1\\ (0,0,1)&\text{ if } m = -1\\ \text{a circle } &\text{ if } -1< m < -1\\ (0,0,-1) & \text{ if } m < = 1\\ \emptyset &\text{ if } m > 1 \end{cases} \] \[\text{Figure 1.2: Critical points of a 2-sphere.}\] \[ f^{-1}((-\infty,m]) = \begin{cases} \emptyset &\text{ if } m < -1\\ \text{a point }&\text{ if } m = -1\\ \text{a half-sphere } &\text{ if } -1< m < -1\\ S^2 & \text{ if } m \geq 1\\ \end{cases} \] \[\text{Figure 1.3: Sublevel pre-image on the 2-sphere domain.}\] Similarly, let’s take the same function to apply on a torus \(T^2\subset\mathbb{R}^3\): \[\text{Figure 1.4: Sublevel pre-image on the torus domain.}\] Here, we can see that the critical points of the \(2-\)sphere and \(2-\)torus with its sub-level set from the height function can tell the 2 spaces apart from the number of \(n-\)dimensional holes. Intuitively, these are the specific topological signature of some shapes in spaces. Here, let’s recall some key definition of critical points in a differential manifold setting. Definition (Manifold) An \(n-\)manifold \(\mathcal{M}\subset\mathbb{R}^n\) is a \(T_2\) topological space (Hausdorff and with countable basis), where there exists a neighborhood \(U\subseteq \mathcal{M}\) for every \(m\in\mathcal{M}\) such that \(U\) is homeomorphic to an open ball in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) induced by the Eucledian metric. Note The definition of manifold in topology refers to manifold with boundary, and manifold without boundary are not manifold. \[\text{Figure 1.5: The torus is a manifold but the mobius strip is not.}\] Definition (Critical Point) For an \(n-\)manifold \(\mathcal{M}\subset\mathbb{R}^n\), let \(f: \mathcal{M} \to \mathbb{R}\). An critical point of \(f\) is \(x\in\mathcal{M}\) such that \(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 0\) \[ \begin{aligned}\text{Figure 1.6:} &\text{ (Top row) Minimum critical point and maximum critical point.}\\ &\text{ (Bottom row) Saddle critical point.} \end{aligned} \] Intuitively, a Morse function is a function maps a manifold domain to \(\mathbb{R}\) with all critical points are non-degenerative (local maximum, minimum, or saddle point). However, a function on a manifold domain does not have second-derivative, but we can define it on local point. Definition (Nondegenerative) Let \(x \in \mathcal{M}\) be a critical point of \(f: \mathcal{M} \to \mathbb{R}\). Consider the tangent space at \(x\), \(T_x\mathcal{M}\), let \(\vec{\mathbf{u}},\vec{\mathbf{v}} \in T_x\mathcal{M}\) be arbitrary. Define \(\partial^{2} f_x(\vec{\mathbf{u}},\vec{\mathbf{v}}) = \vec{\mathbf{u}}(\bar{\vec{\mathbf{v}}}f)(x)\) (where \(\bar{\vec{\mathbf{v}}}\) is an local extension of \(\vec{v}\)), then the Hessians for \(f\) is given by: \[ \begin{align} \mathbf{H}_{f_{ij}} &\equiv \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j} } \\ \mathbf{H}_{f} &= \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{1}^2} & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{1} \partial x_{2} } & \dots & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{1} \partial x_{n} } \\ \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{2} \partial x_{1} } & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{2}^2 } & \dots & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{2} \partial x_{n} } \\ \vdots & \vdots &\ddots & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{n}\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{n} \partial x_{2} } & \dots & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial x_{n}^2 } \end{bmatrix} \end{align} \] The critical point \(x\) is non-degenerative if its Hessian matrix is invertible. Definition (Morse Function) A Morse function is a function that the Hessian value of every critical point is non-degenerative. There are several interesting results from Morse theory that are out of scope for the project. However, informally speaking, one of the relevant finding is that most functions are Morse function. Recall in calculus III, we can approximate a function by its Taylor expansion to the second derivative at a point \(a\) in the domain: \[f(x) \approx f(a) + \frac{1}{1!}f'(a)(x-a) + \frac{1}{2!}f''(a)(x-a)^2\] Then the Morse lemma states that for a Morse function \(f\) with critical point \(a\), then there exists a local chart \((x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)\) such that: \[f(x) = f(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n) = f(a) - \sum_{i=1}^jx_i^2 + \sum_{i=j+1}^nx_i^2 \] Furthermore, for a compact manifold \(\mathcal{M}\), its critical values are only dependent on \(\mathcal{M}\) regardless of choices for the Morse function. There are many fascinating applications of Morse theory in dynamics system, density estimation, etc, however, this project focuses on the discrete version of Morse theory. Namely, we apply the similar idea from persistence homology to find the persistence critical points from the triangulation of our inputs. 1.3 Algebraic topology In simplest term, topologists differentiate abstract spaces by finding its homeomorphic invariants such as compactness, Hausdorff property, connectivity, etc. Algebraic topology turns abstract topological space into combinatorical object to study and compute topological invariant in “holes” of a space using linear algbera. Definition A \(k-\)simplex \(\Delta = [v_0,v_1\dots,v_n]\) is the smallest convex subspace of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) containing \(k+1\) points which are affinitely independent. \[ \begin{aligned}\text{Figure 1.7:} &\text{ From left to right respectively, a 0-simpliex (a point), 1-simplex (an edge),}\\ &\text{ 2-simplex (a filled triangle) and 3-simplex (a filled tetrahedron).} \end{aligned} \] Morse theory study a another type of invariant of differentiable manifold by looking at its differential function, specifically its critical values, defined on that space. Discrete Morse theory uses the same idea by turning these gradient field into “simpler” complexes that can represent the topological space.

Chapter 3 Applications 3.1 Modeling noisy image segmentation This section is to demonstrate an application from discrete Morse theory for image segmentation. The segmentation of medical image (such as CT scan or MRI) requires high accuracy, however, image noises make this task very difficult as clusters could have broken edges or inaccurate gaps. We we implement the segmentation model that are robust to noise using methods from (). The architecture of the algorithm can be simplified as: \[\text{Input Image} \longrightarrow \text{Triangulation } \longrightarrow \text{Density Map } \rho \longrightarrow \text{Persistence diagram }\] From the input image, we can represent each pixel as a point in space. For this model, we assume a triangulation \(\mathcal{K}\) from the input images and we only consider the \(0-\)simplex, \(1-\)simplex, and \(2-\)simplex. We extract the manifold from \(\mathcal{K}\) by the grayscale density map \(\rho: \mathcal{K}\to \mathbb{R}\), in this case, we choose the Laplacian of Gaussian spatial filter for the density map. Lastly, we apply the sublevel set filtration to compute the persistence diagram for the critical points of the diagram for noise modeling, critical points that have long survival interval represent the stable feature of the image, while those have short survival interval accounts for noise. Demonstration We used brain tumour MRI and histopathologic colorectal dataset from Kaggle to demonstrate the algorithm. 3.2 Gene co-expression network analysis In this section, we try to identify the topological structure of the gene co-expression networks belong to patients with bipolar disorder or schizophrenia disorder. Bipolar disorder and schizophrenia are psychiatric disorders that has high mortality rates, which makes the task of diagnosis crucial to improve life quality. Symptoms of bipolar disorder includes manic episodes, which are characterized by increased energy with intense delusion thoughts, while schizophrenia disorder includes psychosis, which are characterized by hallucinations and detachment to reality. In general, different symptoms of psychiatric disorders can sometime look similar enough despite being completely separated, which leads to misdiagnosis. Thus, we want define the problem statement, whether using applications from discrete Morse theory and TDA, we can identify significant biomarkers of these two disorders. \[ \begin{aligned}\text{Figure 4.1:} &\text{ Example of a gene co-expression network.} \end{aligned} \] We collect the gene co-expression network data from NCBI. The gene co-expression network is represented as an undirected network \(G = (V, E)\), where the vertex set \(V\) consists of genes and an edge in the edge set \(E\) represents the similarity in expression level between 2 genes. A clique of a network \(G = (V, E)\) is a sub-network \(C\subset G\), where two distincts vertices in \(C\) are connected by an edge. We used the methods introduced by Kannan et. al. to capture the persistence cliques presented in the gene co-expression networks to compare the two psychiatric disorders. Let \(g_\max\) denotes the maximum degree of \(G\), we define the discrete Morse function on the vertex set of\(G\), \(f: V(G)\to\mathbb{R}\), as: \[f(v) = g_\max - \deg(v) + \epsilon\] where \(\epsilon\) are randomly generated from the uniform distribution \(\text{Uniform}(0,0.5)\). Demonstration The resulted is the barcode diagrams of betti \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) for the bipolar disorder and schizophrenia co-expression network. \[ \begin{aligned}\text{Figure 4.2:} &\text{ (Top row) Persistence diagram of 0-hole respectively for}\\ &\text{ bipolar disorder and schizophrenia network.}\\ &\text{ The bottleneck distance of the two diagrams is } 0.173.\\ &\text{ (Bottom row) Persistence diagram of 1-hole respectively for} \\&\text{ bipolar disorder and schizophrenia network.}\\ &\text{ The bottleneck distance of the two diagrams is } 0.153.\\ \end{aligned} \]

Chapter 4 Conclusion To summarize, we have tried to prove several relevant fundamental ideas of Morse theory in the discrete settings. The main takes away from the project is that with a good choice of a (discrete) Morse function, its non-degenerative critical points can inform a lot about the topological structure of a space. This project also provides two examples of how we can utilize the ideas of persistence critical points through sublevel sets filtration for potential applications image segmentation and network classification. For future works, there are many other applications that we can utilize these results from discrete Morse theory. For example, this paper uses the same ideas to simplify and reconstruct the road network, and this paper uses critical points cancellation from discrete Morse theory to improve the computation of zig-zag persistence. 4.1 References Audin, M., & Damian, M.
